The sphere is not a soyuz but it is a vostok, the soyuz actual re-entry vehicle is bell shaped (see also shenzhou). The vaguely sphere part on top of the soyuz it the orbital part for docking. The seats are in the bell shaped part.

Love your channel!  I'm curious, do u know if the Buran Shuttle had a similar launch profile as the US shuttle?  Specifically did it have to do a roll manuever also and ride upside down into orbit like the American shuttle?  I've never found definitive info about this and was hoping maybe u know.  Personally I've long speculated that the Buran might possibly have launched and flown right-side up instead since the placement of the main engines was in the large core-stage (similar to the ET but with engines), rather than the orbiter itself.  So perhaps the engines of the Energia main stage needed to be below the Buran shuttle during ascent to maintain similar control as the American shuttle (with its engines on the orbiter itself) I'm possibly thinking!  That way in both cases the gimbaling main engines are below the large tank/central booster.  The night time footage of the single Buran launch is not at all clear on this.

For anyone wondering, yes you can go to and stay in space without going into orbit, basically you just need to escape the pull of earths gravity, so the further you get away from earth the less pull there is, there is also a point between the earth and the sun called Lagrangian Point 1 where the gravitational pull from each cancels each other out and and a craft can just sit there.
That's a Vostok capsule, not a Soyuz capsule.

Look at the British Sabre engine, it can liquify the air (at −238 °F) to run the rocket engine in atmosphere up to Mac 5, then use its onboard oxidiser to go Mac 25. The thing that liquifies the air is called a pre-cooler... it (the pre-cooler) cools air at the rate of about 400 Megawatts... You should look up the Sabre engine sometime.

there are mods out there that do things other than make it easier...I haven't played the game in a long time so forgive me for forgetting what they are called, but there are mods that can change the game to be more realistic. You can have the real solar system to actual scale, so instead of taking off and getting into orbit of this tiny little planet, you can actually try from earth (IIRC, 10 times bigger...or is it 6? don't remember) You can have mods where you have to deal with real fuel physics, so instead of being able to relight the engines from a stand still in space, you have to use hypergolic thrusters (or similar) to bring the fuel down to the pumps in order to relite the engine. mods where you have to deal with the speed of light with you maneuvers if you have an unmanned vessel (you can't just instantly control the rovers on mars, can you?) and because of this limitation, you would have to program in your maneuvers.

Not only all that, but I would guess 70% of what is in KSP today were originally mods before they were made stock in the game. even things such as the prograde and retrograde markers on the gimbal were originally mods. I'm pretty sure docking was a mod. mining was a mod. If it wasn't for the modding community, this game would be nothing.

KSP deletes any object in the lower atmosphere if physics isn't enabled on it. A few versions back, they upped the physics distance in the atmosphere from 2km to something much larger, like 20 or more. I think if you used your remaining RCS on the two capsules to make their reentry paths closer, you might have pulled it off. That would have meant angling the Apollo capsule to get more lift, and digging the Soyuz deeper, I think.

Hi Tim

The inflatable airlock was only ever used on the Voshkod 2 mission (where Alexei Leonov did his famous space walk). On the Apollo/Soyuz mission they used an airlock adapter module which allowed them to transition from the pure oxygen atmosphere of Apollo to the air mixture atmosphere of Soyuz. There were no EVAs on that mission.
